questions.text: Which planet is closest to the Sun?
questions.explanation: Mercury orbits at an average distance of about 36 million miles from the Sun, making it the closest planet.

questions.text: What is the largest planet in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Jupiter has a mass more than twice that of all the other planets combined and a diameter of about 86,881 miles.

questions.text: How long does it take light from the Sun to reach Earth?
questions.explanation: Sunlight travels approximately 93 million miles to Earth, taking about 8 minutes and 20 seconds at the speed of light.

questions.text: Who was the first human to walk on the Moon?
questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong stepped onto the lunar surface on July 20, 1969, during the Apollo 11 mission.

questions.text: What galaxy do we live in?
questions.explanation: Our solar system is located in the Milky Way galaxy, a barred spiral galaxy containing 100-400 billion stars.

questions.text: Which planet is known as the 'Red Planet'?
questions.explanation: Mars appears reddish due to iron oxide (rust) prevalent on its surface.

questions.text: What is the name of the first artificial satellite launched into space?
questions.explanation: Sputnik 1 was launched by the Soviet Union on October 4, 1957, marking the start of the space age.

questions.text: How many planets are in our solar system?
questions.explanation: There are 8 recognized planets. Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet by the IAU in 2006.

questions.text: What is the hottest planet in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Despite being farther from the Sun than Mercury, Venus has a thick CO2 atmosphere that traps heat, reaching surface temperatures of about 900 degrees F.

questions.text: What type of star is our Sun?
questions.explanation: The Sun is classified as a G-type main-sequence star (G2V), commonly called a yellow dwarf.

questions.text: Which space telescope was launched in 1990 and orbits Earth?
questions.explanation: The Hubble Space Telescope was deployed from the Space Shuttle Discovery on April 24, 1990.

questions.text: What force keeps planets in orbit around the Sun?
questions.explanation: Gravity is the fundamental force that keeps planets, moons, and other objects in orbit around more massive bodies.

questions.text: Which planet has the most moons in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Saturn has over 140 confirmed moons, surpassing Jupiter's count of confirmed natural satellites.

questions.text: What is the closest star to Earth after the Sun?
questions.explanation: Proxima Centauri, part of the Alpha Centauri system, is about 4.24 light-years from Earth.

questions.text: What are Saturn's rings primarily made of?
questions.explanation: Saturn's rings are composed mostly of ice particles ranging from tiny grains to house-sized chunks, along with rocky debris.

questions.text: Who was the first human in space?
questions.explanation: Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin became the first human in space on April 12, 1961, aboard Vostok 1.

questions.text: What is a light-year a measure of?
questions.explanation: A light-year is the distance light travels in one year, approximately 5.88 trillion miles (9.46 trillion km).

questions.text: Which planet rotates on its side with an axial tilt of about 98 degrees?
questions.explanation: Uranus has an extreme axial tilt of about 98 degrees, likely caused by a massive ancient collision.

questions.text: What is the name of the region beyond Neptune where many icy bodies orbit?
questions.explanation: The Kuiper Belt extends from Neptune's orbit (about 30 AU) outward to roughly 50 AU and contains dwarf planets like Pluto and Eris.

questions.text: What phenomenon occurs when a massive star collapses and its gravity is so strong that nothing can escape, not even light?
questions.explanation: A black hole forms when a massive star's core collapses, creating a region of spacetime with gravity so intense that nothing can escape its event horizon.

questions.text: Which NASA rover landed on Mars in February 2021?
questions.explanation: The Perseverance rover landed in Jezero Crater on February 18, 2021, to search for signs of ancient microbial life.

questions.text: What is the Great Red Spot on Jupiter?
questions.explanation: The Great Red Spot is a persistent high-pressure storm system larger than Earth that has been raging for at least 350 years.

questions.text: Which constellation contains the North Star (Polaris)?
questions.explanation: Polaris is located at the tip of the handle of Ursa Minor (the Little Dipper).

questions.text: What is the name of the boundary where the Sun's solar wind is stopped by interstellar medium?
questions.explanation: The heliopause is the boundary where the Sun's solar wind is no longer strong enough to push against interstellar gas.

questions.text: How old is the Sun, approximately?
questions.explanation: The Sun formed approximately 4.6 billion years ago from a collapsing cloud of hydrogen and helium gas.

questions.text: What is the International Space Station's approximate orbital altitude?
questions.explanation: The ISS orbits at an altitude of approximately 250 miles (408 km) above Earth's surface.

questions.text: Which moon of Jupiter is believed to have a subsurface ocean beneath its icy crust?
questions.explanation: Europa is one of the most promising candidates for extraterrestrial life due to evidence of a liquid water ocean beneath its ice shell.

questions.text: What causes a solar eclipse?

options.A: Earth passes between the Sun and Moon
options.B: The Moon passes between Earth and the Sun
options.D: Earth's shadow falls on the Sun

questions.explanation: A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes between Earth and the Sun, blocking sunlight from reaching parts of Earth.

questions.text: Which planet has the shortest year (orbital period)?
questions.explanation: Mercury completes one orbit around the Sun in just about 88 Earth days, the shortest of any planet.

questions.text: What element makes up most of the Sun's mass?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen makes up about 73% of the Sun's mass. Nuclear fusion converts hydrogen into helium in the Sun's core.

questions.text: What was the name of the space shuttle that tragically broke apart 73 seconds after launch in 1986?
questions.explanation: Space Shuttle Challenger broke apart on January 28, 1986, due to the failure of an O-ring seal on a solid rocket booster.

questions.text: What is the approximate age of the universe?
questions.explanation: Based on observations of the cosmic microwave background radiation, the universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old.

questions.text: Which dwarf planet was formerly classified as the ninth planet of our solar system?
questions.explanation: Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet by the International Astronomical Union in August 2006.

questions.text: What is the name of the largest volcano in the solar system, located on Mars?
questions.explanation: Olympus Mons on Mars stands about 13.6 miles (22 km) high, roughly 2.5 times the height of Mount Everest.

questions.text: What does NASA stand for?
questions.explanation: NASA stands for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, established in 1958.

questions.text: Which spacecraft was the first to fly past Pluto?
questions.explanation: NASA's New Horizons spacecraft performed a flyby of Pluto on July 14, 2015, sending back the first close-up images.

questions.text: What is the Asteroid Belt located between?
questions.explanation: The main Asteroid Belt lies between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter, roughly 2.2 to 3.2 AU from the Sun.

questions.text: What is the Chandrasekhar limit?

options.A: The maximum distance a telescope can see
options.B: The maximum mass of a stable white dwarf star (about 1.4 solar masses)
options.C: The speed limit of light in a vacuum
options.D: The closest distance a spacecraft can approach a black hole

questions.explanation: The Chandrasekhar limit (about 1.4 solar masses) is the maximum mass a white dwarf can have before it collapses further into a neutron star or black hole.

questions.text: Which famous astronomer proposed the heliocentric model of the solar system?
questions.explanation: Nicolaus Copernicus published his heliocentric theory in 1543, proposing that the Earth and planets revolve around the Sun.

questions.text: What is a supernova?

options.B: The explosive death of a massive star

questions.explanation: A supernova is a powerful explosion that occurs at the end of a massive star's life, briefly outshining an entire galaxy.

questions.text: Which planet has the longest day (slowest rotation)?
questions.explanation: Venus rotates extremely slowly and retrograde. One Venusian sidereal day takes about 243 Earth days.

questions.text: What is the cosmic microwave background (CMB)?

options.C: Residual radiation from the early universe after the Big Bang

questions.explanation: The CMB is thermal radiation left over from about 380,000 years after the Big Bang, discovered accidentally in 1965 by Penzias and Wilson.

questions.text: Which moon in our solar system has a thick atmosphere and liquid methane lakes?
questions.explanation: Titan, Saturn's largest moon, has a dense nitrogen atmosphere and is the only known moon with stable liquid on its surface (methane and ethane lakes).

questions.text: What year did the Apollo 11 mission land on the Moon?
questions.explanation: Apollo 11 landed on the Moon on July 20, 1969, in the Sea of Tranquility.

questions.text: What is the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram used for?

options.B: Classifying stars by luminosity and temperature

questions.explanation: The H-R diagram plots stars by their luminosity versus surface temperature, revealing stellar classification groups like the main sequence, giants, and white dwarfs.

questions.text: Which spacecraft carried the Golden Record, a message intended for extraterrestrial life?
questions.explanation: The Voyager 1 and 2 spacecraft, launched in 1977, each carry a Golden Record containing sounds and images of Earth.

questions.text: What is the name of the supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way?
questions.explanation: Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*) is the supermassive black hole at the center of our galaxy, with a mass of about 4 million times that of the Sun.

questions.text: What process powers the Sun and other stars?
questions.explanation: Stars are powered by nuclear fusion, where hydrogen atoms fuse into helium in the core, releasing enormous amounts of energy.

questions.text: Which planet has the most prominent ring system visible from Earth?
questions.explanation: Saturn's ring system is the most extensive and visible, stretching up to 282,000 km from the planet but only about 10 meters thick.

questions.text: What is a neutron star?

options.A: A star made entirely of neutrons that forms after a supernova
options.B: A star with no electrical charge
options.C: A star that emits only neutron particles
options.D: A theoretical star that has never been observed

questions.explanation: A neutron star is the collapsed core of a massive star after a supernova, composed almost entirely of neutrons, incredibly dense and typically only about 20 km in diameter.

questions.text: Which space probe entered orbit around Saturn in 2004?
questions.explanation: The Cassini spacecraft entered Saturn's orbit on July 1, 2004, and studied the planet and its moons until its planned deorbit in September 2017.

questions.text: What is the Oort Cloud?

options.B: A theoretical spherical shell of icy objects surrounding the solar system at great distance
options.C: A ring of dust around Jupiter
options.D: A galaxy cluster near the Milky Way

questions.explanation: The Oort Cloud is a hypothesized spherical region of icy planetesimals extending roughly 2,000 to 100,000 AU from the Sun, believed to be the source of long-period comets.

questions.text: What is the brightest star in the night sky as seen from Earth?
questions.explanation: Sirius (the Dog Star) in Canis Major has an apparent magnitude of -1.46, making it the brightest star visible from Earth.

questions.text: What are the two main types of planets in our solar system?
questions.explanation: The four inner terrestrial planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars) are rocky, while the four outer Jovian planets (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune) are gas or ice giants.

questions.text: What was the first space station?
questions.explanation: Salyut 1 was the first space station, launched by the Soviet Union on April 19, 1971.

questions.text: What is the term for the point in a planet's orbit when it is closest to the Sun?
questions.explanation: Perihelion is the point in a planet's elliptical orbit nearest to the Sun. Aphelion is the farthest point.

questions.text: Which constellation is shaped like a hunter and contains the stars Betelgeuse and Rigel?
questions.explanation: Orion the Hunter is one of the most recognizable constellations, with Betelgeuse marking a shoulder and Rigel marking a foot.

questions.text: What is dark matter?

options.A: Matter that absorbs all light like a black hole
options.B: Invisible matter that does not interact with light but exerts gravitational effects

questions.explanation: Dark matter is a hypothetical form of matter that does not emit or interact with electromagnetic radiation but accounts for about 27% of the universe's mass-energy.

questions.text: Which Apollo mission was the famous 'successful failure' that safely returned its crew after an oxygen tank explosion?
questions.explanation: Apollo 13 experienced an oxygen tank explosion on April 13, 1970. The crew used the lunar module as a lifeboat and returned safely to Earth.

questions.text: What is the James Webb Space Telescope primarily designed to observe?

options.B: Infrared light from distant galaxies, stars, and exoplanets

questions.explanation: JWST is an infrared telescope designed to see the earliest galaxies, study star formation, and analyze exoplanet atmospheres. It launched on December 25, 2021.

questions.text: What is a pulsar?

options.A: A planet that pulses with heat
options.B: A rapidly rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation

questions.explanation: A pulsar is a highly magnetized, rapidly spinning neutron star that emits beams of radiation from its poles, appearing to pulse as it rotates.

questions.text: Which planet rotates the fastest in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Jupiter completes one rotation in about 9 hours and 56 minutes, despite being the largest planet in our solar system.

questions.text: What is the Roche limit?

options.A: The maximum size of a star
options.B: The distance within which a celestial body will be torn apart by tidal forces
options.C: The minimum mass required for fusion
options.D: The edge of the observable universe

questions.explanation: The Roche limit is the minimum distance at which a moon or other body can orbit without being torn apart by tidal forces from the larger body it orbits.

questions.text: Who first observed the moons of Jupiter through a telescope?
questions.explanation: Galileo Galilei observed Jupiter's four largest moons (Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto) in January 1610, now called the Galilean moons.

questions.text: What is the largest known structure in the observable universe?
questions.explanation: The Hercules-Corona Borealis Great Wall is a massive galaxy filament stretching about 10 billion light-years, the largest known structure in the observable universe.

questions.text: What is the Doppler effect used for in astronomy?

options.B: Determining the chemical composition of planets
options.C: Measuring the velocity of objects moving toward or away from us via wavelength shift
options.D: Counting the number of stars in a galaxy

questions.explanation: In astronomy, the Doppler effect causes light from objects moving away to shift toward red (redshift) and toward blue (blueshift) for approaching objects.

questions.text: Which moon of Saturn shoots geysers of water ice into space?
questions.explanation: Enceladus has active cryovolcanic geysers at its south pole that shoot plumes of water vapor and ice particles into space, feeding Saturn's E ring.

questions.text: What is the speed of light in a vacuum?
questions.explanation: Light travels at approximately 186,000 miles per second (about 300,000 km/s) in a vacuum.

questions.text: What is a quasar?

options.B: An extremely luminous active galactic nucleus powered by a supermassive black hole

questions.explanation: Quasars are among the most luminous objects in the universe, powered by accretion of material onto supermassive black holes at the centers of distant galaxies.

questions.text: Which planet has winds that can exceed 1,200 mph, the fastest in the solar system?
questions.explanation: Neptune has the fastest winds in the solar system, with speeds reaching over 1,200 mph (2,000 km/h).

questions.text: What did Edwin Hubble discover in the 1920s?
questions.explanation: Edwin Hubble demonstrated that galaxies are moving away from each other, showing that the universe is expanding, which became Hubble's Law.

questions.text: What is the Crab Nebula?

options.A: A planetary nebula around a dying star
options.B: A supernova remnant from an explosion observed in 1054 AD
options.C: A region where new stars are forming
options.D: A galaxy in the Virgo cluster

questions.explanation: The Crab Nebula (M1) is the remnant of a supernova that was observed by Chinese and other astronomers in 1054 AD. It contains a pulsar at its center.

questions.text: What is the name of the closest major galaxy to the Milky Way?
questions.explanation: The Andromeda Galaxy (M31) is about 2.5 million light-years away and is the nearest large galaxy to the Milky Way. It is expected to collide with our galaxy in about 4.5 billion years.

questions.text: What are Lagrange points?

options.B: Positions in space where gravitational forces of two large bodies balance with orbital motion, allowing a small object to remain stable

questions.explanation: Lagrange points are five positions in a two-body orbital system where a small object can maintain a stable position. JWST orbits at the Sun-Earth L2 point.

questions.text: Which element is created in the cores of massive stars and is essential for life on Earth?
questions.explanation: Carbon is formed through the triple-alpha process in the cores of massive stars and is the basis of all known life. As Carl Sagan said, we are made of star stuff.

questions.text: What was the first spacecraft to land on another planet?
questions.explanation: The Soviet Venera 7 became the first spacecraft to successfully land on another planet when it touched down on Venus on December 15, 1970, and transmitted data for about 23 minutes.

questions.text: What is an exoplanet?

options.A: A planet that has been ejected from its solar system
options.B: A planet that orbits a star outside our solar system
options.D: A gas cloud that could become a planet

questions.explanation: An exoplanet is any planet that orbits a star other than our Sun. Thousands have been discovered, many by the Kepler Space Telescope.

questions.text: What is a white dwarf?

options.A: A very small, hot, newly formed star
options.B: The dense remnant core of a low-to-medium mass star after it sheds its outer layers
options.C: A star hidden behind a nebula

questions.explanation: A white dwarf is the remnant of a star (like our Sun) that has exhausted its nuclear fuel and shed its outer layers, leaving behind a dense, Earth-sized core.

questions.text: What phenomenon causes the tails of comets?

options.B: Solar radiation and solar wind causing sublimation of the comet's ice
options.D: Magnetic fields in the solar system

questions.explanation: As comets approach the Sun, solar radiation and solar wind cause ices to sublimate, releasing gas and dust that form the coma and tail, always pointing away from the Sun.

questions.text: What is gravitational lensing?

options.B: A telescope that uses gravity to focus light
options.C: The bending of light from a distant source by a massive object's gravity, as predicted by general relativity
options.D: The effect of gravity on radio signals

questions.explanation: Gravitational lensing occurs when a massive object like a galaxy cluster bends the light from a more distant object, magnifying and distorting its image, as predicted by Einstein's general relativity.
